snippet.title:
What to eat when training for a marathon Free Webinar. https://www1.gotomeeting.com/register/386856313 . I have been lucky enough to secure one of Australia's top sports nutritionalists and food coach Dr Shirely MciLvenny to talk about Marathon Nutrition and teaching your body to utilize fat for energy when training and racing. It is really exciting cutting edge information. Click the link to secure your place - I look forward to seeing you online - Warm Regards Kerry (Marathon Girl) #marathontraining #marathonrunners #marathonnutrition #marathongirl ﻿

The best half #marathon training schedule for #beginners running plans available fore free can be found at logyourrun.com. However, remember that a #RunningProgram won't give any advice about your #MarathonDiet, equipment, injury prevention, blisters, chaffing and a multitude of other considerations which you won't know about until it's too late.
Read more: http://bit.ly/1aMyxmW﻿

Yesterday 9,3 km race, part of my marathon training. My idea was to run at 5' per km pace but I ended in 44:02 minutes at 4:45 minutes per km and good sensation. In a couple of weeks I have a half marathon race and in November 27th the Valencia Marathon. #running﻿
Meer weergevenMinder weergeven

I officially started my half marathon training today! I did 30 minutes of stations after work with some friends and then I set off on a 3 mile jog. The stations help to tone my muscles that I am not 100% happy with yet (arms, thighs, abs...well mostly everything). I locked up my classroom and literally ran straight out my back door. I love my Nike running app or I swear I would always be sticking to a treadmill. I turned my app on and did not start heading back until I was almost done running 3 miles. The run took me about 35 minutes (I did have to stop and talk to my mother on the phone for a minute or 2) but overall, I think that is pretty okay. I am not a sprinter, I am just focused on distance and not stopping because my body feels like I can't go any farther. As far as my diet goes....well I didn't have one today. This week is full of yummy holiday goodies at lunch for the teachers. One of my silly reasons for loosing weight was because I actually love food so much, I wanted to be able to eat without stressing out about how fat I was or how much MORE weight that brownie was going to make me gain. Needless to say, I am so excited about the holidays and not stressing over my weight. I am not planning on hard core watching what I eat until after the holidays. However, I am making sure that I get the proper amount of water, vitamins, protein, and carbs that I will need for training. It is going to be so strange (but yet fun) changing from the low carb diet that I have been maintaining for almost a year now to a diet full of "good" carbs. I am pretty happy that I have a reason to eat pasta and mashed potatoes again!!﻿

Marathon training requires toeing that blurry line between pushing your limits and overtraining, which can often lead to physical and mental burnout. So, how do you train to your potential without falling victim to burnout? We examine some of the main causes of burnout and learn how to avoid them in our training. http://runnersconnect.net/running-training-articles/marathon-training-burnout-causes/﻿
Meer weergevenMinder weergeven · Vertalen

This is week 15 of 18 of my Marathon training. It's been a challenging commitment spending so many days preparing for this, but I think I'm on track for the big run on June 1st. Stats of this run: I'm Running a Marathon
My goal is to run the 26miles/42km marathon in under 4 1/2 hours. I've only done one other marathon in my life in 1998 and my time was 4 hrs 50 minutes. I considered it a failure cause I walked the last 10km. Here's a video of a recent training run: Marathon Training & My Day Job﻿
